Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two millennia before the likes of Usain Bolt
came onto the scene, humans were pitting their strength and speed against each other. It’s thought that the first Olympic games
were held in 776 BC in ancient Greece, and the tradition carried on under the Roman Empire. An Olympic Truce was even established by the
Greeks which was expected to be adhered to so people could spectate and compete in safety. The 4 year tradition, and in some ways the
truce, is upheld today, just with much stronger and faster people competing. The closest the ancients had to a vehicle
race was with chariots, and you could say that humanity has significantly improved when
it comes to speed on wheels. Today we are going to look at what speed humans
are capable of, in this episode of The Infographics Show, How Fast Can We Go? Don’t forget to subscribe and click the
bell button so that you can be part of our Notification Squad. We’ll start with our bodies. Maybe the best of the ancient runners was
Leonidas of Rhodes who won three stade, sprint races, (including the 200 yards and 400 yards)
in each of four consecutive Olympics from 164-152 BCE. The main event was the 200 yards (about 180
meters) which was the equivalent of the modern 100 meters. He was regarded as the Usain Bolt of today,
or the Michael Johnson of not so long ago, and was even winning races at the ripe old
age of 36. His medal tally was only beaten 2,168 years
later by swimmer Michael Phelps. No one knows of course how fast he ran, but
guesses range from 24-26 seconds for 180 meters. The fastest recorded 100 meters time is held
by Usain Bolt at 9.58 seconds, which means he was running at an average of 10.43 meters
per second or 23.34 mph (37.6 kph). It’s thought that at about 68 meters, he
hit his fastest speed, which was 12.34 meters per second or 27.61 mph (44.4 kph). This is about as fast as any human has ever
run, and it’s about the speed of a galloping horse. We can compare that to one of the earliest
recorded sprint records, that of American sprinter Tom Burke who won the 100 meters
at Athens in 1896 in a time of 12 seconds. While Bolt would be able to outrun a Velociraptor,
he would not be able to keep it up for long. The fastest recorded long distance time was
set by Kenyan Dennis Kimetto in 2014. His time for the marathon was 2 hours 2 minutes
and 57 seconds. This averaged at 4 minutes 41 seconds a mile. It’s thought a sub-2 hour marathon time
is on the way, which means running the entire 26.2 miles (42 kilometers) at 13.1 mph (21
kph). Try that at the gym on the treadmill for even
a few hundred meters and you’ll see just how incredible this man is. The average adult male jogs at about 8.3 mph
(13.3 kph), which is a 27 second 100 meters. Women jog at an average of 6.5 mph (10.4 kph)
or a 34 second 100 meters. It’s thought that even fit and healthy non-athlete
adults that can run very well will only average around 15.9 miles per hour (25.5 kph), which
would mean a 100 meter time of around 13-14 seconds. The average healthy human walks at around
3 miles per hour (4.8 kph). Let’s now have a look at swimming. It’s reported that almost half of the world’s
population can’t swim, including 44 percent of Americans according to the U.S. Red Cross. Although the report said some people believed
they could swim, but weren’t able to swim well enough to be adjudged safe in the water. The fastest person in the world, ever, is
Brazilian César Cielo. Much has been said about the great Michael
Phelps taking on a great white shark in a race, but in terms of raw speed he’s slower
than Cielo. His time of 46.91 seconds in the 100 meters
freestyle is the fastest a human has ever swum, giving him an average speed of about
5.3 mph (8.5 kph). That’s faster than the average jogging speed
of the average male. It’s thought Phelps’ average speed when
he won gold in the 100 meters freestyle relay was about 4.7 mph (7.5 mph). The two men are about the same speed as the
average cod, but both would get trounced in a race with a great white shark that can reach
speeds of 25 mph (40kph). The average human that can swim freestyle
is a speed of just 2 mph (3.2 kph). But how fast has a human ever travelled? That would be astronauts on NASA’s Apollo
10 mission when they reached a top speed of 24,791 mph (39,897 kph). Elon Musk’s SpaceX plans to colonize Mars,
and to get there they need a fair bit of power. The rocket which will be used is nicknamed
the BFS, and SpaceX says it will reach cruising speeds of 62,000 mph (99.77 thousand kph). British Royal Air Force fighter pilot Andy
Green holds the world land speed record, set in 1997. He got up to 763 mph (1,227 kph) in his Thrust
supersonic car in the Black Rock desert, USA. In 1898 a Frenchman broke the same land speed
record in his electric car, reaching a speed of 39.24 mph (63 kph). The fastest two wheels have ever gone is 394
mph (634 kph) with the TOP 1 Ack Attack ridden by Rocky Robinson at the Bonneville Speedway
in Utah. These machines are not built for the road,
however, but some road cars and bikes can reach impressive speeds. The Bugatti Veyron is listed as the world’s
fastest road car, able to reach speeds of 268 mph (431 kph) and the fastest thing on
two wheels on the road is the Kawasaki Ninja H2R. It can reach speeds of 249 mph (400 kph). The fastest person on a bicycle was Dutch
cyclist Fred Rompelberg, who travelled at a speed of 167 mph (268 kph) in 1995. As for rail, the winner for the fastest speed
is US air force colonel John Stapp, who reached 632 mph (1017 kph) on his rocket sled. Passenger trains don’t get anywhere near
that, but some are very fast. The French TVG has an average speed when taking
folks around France of about 200 mph (321 kph), but it also holds the record for the
fastest speed ever on a national rail system of 357 mph (574 kph). At that speed you could realistically commute
from Paris to offices in the UK, Germany, Spain, and other nations surrounding France. Japan’s magnetically levitated MLX01 maglev
has hit a speed of 361 mph (580 kph), but that was only in testing. Many countries are presently developing high-speed
trains as an alternative to air and road travel. You’d think the perfect country for such
a system would be the United States, given its size, population, and long distances its
citizens often travel. This is actually a matter of controversy,
as an article in Forbes points out in 2017. There are many reasons, and one is that the
U.S. as you’ll know from our other shows spends little on transportation compared to
its military. Andy Kunz, president of the U.S. High Speed Rail Association, once said in
an interview that lobbying efforts Spirit of Australiafrom oil, aviation and highway
companies were also blocking high-speed rail advancement. Perhaps Elon Musk’s Boring Company and its
underground Hyperloop project might happen before high-speed rail. On water the record was set by Australian
Ken Warby in his Spirit of Australia wooden speedboat, which reached 317.596 mph (511
kph) in 1978. It’s not a record many people try to break
as they often end up dead. Long-time British record holder Donald Campbell
was one of those people, and there were many more. Record holder Warby told Wired in an interview
after he retired, “When you look down that lake, you better have all your homework done,
because your chances are 50-50 – and you better be in the right 50 percent.” It might be safer to travel by ocean liner. The fastest was the SS United States, that
averaged a speed of 29 mph (62 kph). The Titanic was a good 8 mph slower. Finally, we take to the air. Surprisingly, the record set for a manned
aircraft was as far back as 1967. That was when a hypersonic rocket-powered
aircraft called the North American X-15 hit a speed of 4,520 mph (7,274 kph) with American
air force pilot William Knight at the controls. Passenger jets average a speed of 575 mph
(925 kph) but may reach up to about 745 mph (1198 kph). The fastest ever passenger plane was the British-French
made Concorde, which reached speeds of 1,354 mph (2,180 kph). A plane called the Baby Boom is set to beat
that speed in 2023, but it will be a much smaller machine. That’s the end of the show today. Why not tell us your fastest speed? Are you better than the average Joe? What’s the fastest you’ve ever travelled,
on land, in the water, in the air? Let us know in the comments! And if you liked this video, be sure to check
out our other video called Can Aliens See Dinosaurs! Thanks for watching, and, as always, don’t
forget to like, share, and subscribe. See you next time!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Usain Bolt’s hit his fastest speed at ___ mph.
Options: A. 12.34, B. 23.34, C. 27.61, D. 44.4
Correct Option: C

Question 1: In what year were the first Olympic games held in ancient Greece? Options: A. 500 BC, B. 776 BC, C. 1000 BC, D. 1500 BC Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main event in the ancient Olympic games, and what is its equivalent in modern times? Options: A. 400 yards, equivalent to modern 200 meters, B. 200 yards, equivalent to modern 100 meters, C. 100 yards, equivalent to modern 50 meters, D. 800 yards, equivalent to modern 400 meters Correct Option: B
Question 3: If a person can jog at an average speed of 8.3 mph, how long would it take them to complete a 100-meter dash? Options: A. 10 seconds, B. 15 seconds, C. 20 seconds, D. 27 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the fastest recorded 100 meters time, and who holds this record? Options: A. 9.58 seconds, held by Usain Bolt, B. 10.43 seconds, held by Michael Johnson, C. 12 seconds, held by Tom Burke, D. 15 seconds, held by Leonidas of Rhodes Correct Option: A
Question 5: Compare the average speed of a fit and healthy non-athlete adult to the average speed of a galloping horse. Which one is faster? Options: A. The non-athlete adult is faster, B. The galloping horse is faster, C. They have the same speed, D. There is not enough information to compare Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the fastest recorded long-distance time for a marathon, and who holds this record? Options: A. 2 hours 2 minutes and 57 seconds, held by Dennis Kimetto, B. 2 hours 30 minutes and 57 seconds, held by Usain Bolt, C. 3 hours 2 minutes and 57 seconds, held by Michael Phelps, D. 4 hours 2 minutes and 57 seconds, held by Leonidas of Rhodes Correct Option: A
Question 7: Analyze the relationship between the average speed of a person jogging and the average speed of a person swimming freestyle. What can be concluded? Options: A. The average jogging speed is faster than the average swimming speed, B. The average swimming speed is faster than the average jogging speed, C. The average jogging speed is equal to the average swimming speed, D. There is no relationship between jogging and swimming speeds Correct Option: A
Question 8: Synthesize the information about the fastest recorded speeds in different modes of transportation (land, water, air). What can be concluded about the safety of these modes? Options: A. Land transportation is the safest, followed by air and then water, B. Air transportation is the safest, followed by land and then water, C. Water transportation is the most dangerous, while land and air have varying levels of safety, D. There is no clear conclusion about the safety of these modes Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the potential benefits and drawbacks of developing high-speed trains as an alternative to air and road travel in the United States. What is a major obstacle to this development? Options: A. High costs and lack of funding, B. Lobbying efforts from oil, aviation, and highway companies, C. Limited technological capabilities, D. Environmental concerns Correct Option: B
Question 10: Justify the claim that the fastest recorded speed of a manned aircraft (4,520 mph) is impressive. What factors contribute to this achievement? Options: A. The aircraft's design and rocket-powered propulsion system, B. The skill and experience of the pilot, William Knight, C. The favorable weather conditions during the flight, D. All of the above factors Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
Two millennia before the likes of Usain Bolt
came onto the scene, humans were pitting their strength and speed against each other. It’s thought that the first Olympic games
were held in 776 BC in ancient Greece, and the tradition carried on under the Roman Empire. An Olympic Truce was even established by the
Greeks which was expected to be adhered to so people could spectate and compete in safety. The 4 year tradition, and in some ways the
truce, is upheld today, just with much stronger and faster people competing. The closest the ancients had to a vehicle
race was with chariots, and you could say that humanity has significantly improved when
it comes to speed on wheels. Today we are going to look at what speed humans
are capable of, in this episode of The Infographics Show, How Fast Can We Go? Don’t forget to subscribe and click the
bell button so that you can be part of our Notification Squad. We’ll start with our bodies. Maybe the best of the ancient runners was
Leonidas of Rhodes who won three stade, sprint races, (including the 200 yards and 400 yards)
in each of four consecutive Olympics from 164-152 BCE. The main event was the 200 yards (about 180
meters) which was the equivalent of the modern 100 meters. He was regarded as the Usain Bolt of today,
or the Michael Johnson of not so long ago, and was even winning races at the ripe old
age of 36. His medal tally was only beaten 2,168 years
later by swimmer Michael Phelps. No one knows of course how fast he ran, but
guesses range from 24-26 seconds for 180 meters. The fastest recorded 100 meters time is held
by Usain Bolt at 9.58 seconds, which means he was running at an average of 10.43 meters
per second or 23.34 mph (37.6 kph). It’s thought that at about 68 meters, he
hit his fastest speed, which was 12.34 meters per second or 27.61 mph (44.4 kph). This is about as fast as any human has ever
run, and it’s about the speed of a galloping horse. We can compare that to one of the earliest
recorded sprint records, that of American sprinter Tom Burke who won the 100 meters
at Athens in 1896 in a time of 12 seconds. While Bolt would be able to outrun a Velociraptor,
he would not be able to keep it up for long. The fastest recorded long distance time was
set by Kenyan Dennis Kimetto in 2014. His time for the marathon was 2 hours 2 minutes
and 57 seconds. This averaged at 4 minutes 41 seconds a mile. It’s thought a sub-2 hour marathon time
is on the way, which means running the entire 26.2 miles (42 kilometers) at 13.1 mph (21
kph). Try that at the gym on the treadmill for even
a few hundred meters and you’ll see just how incredible this man is. The average adult male jogs at about 8.3 mph
(13.3 kph), which is a 27 second 100 meters. Women jog at an average of 6.5 mph (10.4 kph)
or a 34 second 100 meters. It’s thought that even fit and healthy non-athlete

in Utah. These machines are not built for the road,
however, but some road cars and bikes can reach impressive speeds. The Bugatti Veyron is listed as the world’s

two wheels on the road is the Kawasaki Ninja H2R. It can reach speeds of 249 mph (400 kph). The fastest person on a bicycle was Dutch

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey there! Welcome to Life Noggin! If you’ve never had a nosebleed before,
the first one can be terrifying. Especially if you’re young when it happens and have
no idea what’s going on. All you know is that blood is leaking out of your face...for
no reason. But of course, now that you are older you
know that there is a reason your nose started to bleed...you were experiencing a condition
known as epistaxis. When this occurs, it can be one of two types: anterior or posterior.
More than likely, you’ll get an anterior nosebleed which is caused by irritation to
blood vessels in the nasal septum. That’s the part of your nose that separates
your two nostrils. And it’s also the part of your nose that can get deviated, which
can lead to difficulty breathing. And fun fact: it’s estimated that 80% of people
have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum. If I had a nose, I could attest to
that, but sadly my face is pretty featureless. As you can see. But a block can dream! Anyway, in the nasal septum is an area called
the Kiesselbach plexus, where four different arteries come together to form a network of
blood vessels. So, when this area is irritated by either a vigorous blow or a roaming finger,
some of the blood vessels may break. And then you get blood running down your face and possibly
down the back of your throat. But what about dry air? In the northern hemisphere,
winter is coming up and with it comes a lot of nosebleeds. The decreased humidity and
temperature prevent your nose from getting the moisture it needs. This then makes the
mucous membrane more susceptible to bleeding and...Voila! You’ve got blood leaking down
your nostril. The only thing more unappealing than that is saying the words “mucous membrane.” So how do you stop the blood? It’s recommended
that you pinch the soft part of your nose for ten minutes, making sure to keep the nostrils
closed. This pressure helps the blood to clot and stops the bleeding. Oh, and lean forward
during this because otherwise, as I previously mentioned, blood can leak down the back of
your throat. (Which you don't want.) However, if you are lucky enough to be near a doctor when you get a nosebleed,
if they can easily see the broken blood vessel, they may be able to cauterize, or seal, it
using silver nitrate. So do yourself a favor and keep all fingers
and foreign objects away from your nostrils. Your nose and future self will thank you. Have you ever had a nosebleed? Do you get them often?  If you're comfortable with sharing let us know in the comments or tell us what we should we talk about next. And if you want even more Life Noggin, check out this video we did on would happen if all cat suddenly died. Yeah! Oh and make sure you follow us on Facebook and Twitter As always my name is Blocko, this is been life noggin, don't forget to keep on thinking.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An _______ nosebleed is caused by irritation to blood vessels in the nasal septum.
Options: A. anterior, B. posterior
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the medical term for a nosebleed? Options: A. Epistaxis, B. Rhinitis, C. Sinusitis, D. Pharyngitis Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which part of the nose separates the two nostrils and can get deviated, leading to difficulty breathing? Options: A. Nasal cavity, B. Nasal septum, C. Turbinate bones, D. Olfactory epithelium Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the estimated percentage of people who have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum? Options: A. 40%, B. 60%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 4: A person experiences a nosebleed due to dry air. What is the likely cause of the bleeding? Options: A. Increased humidity and temperature, B. Decreased humidity and temperature, C. Allergies, D. Infection Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the recommended method to stop a nosebleed? Options: A. Pinch the hard part of the nose for 5 minutes, B. Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes, C. Apply ice to the nose, D. Use nasal decongestants Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is it recommended to lean forward while trying to stop a nosebleed? Options: A. To prevent blood from leaking down the back of the throat, B. To increase blood flow to the nose, C. To reduce swelling, D. To ease breathing Correct Option: A
Question 7: If a doctor can easily see the broken blood vessel, what method may they use to stop the bleeding? Options: A. Cauterization with silver nitrate, B. Nasal packing, C. Antibiotics, D. Surgery Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the name of the area in the nasal septum where four different arteries come together to form a network of blood vessels? Options: A. Kiesselbach plexus, B. Nasal cavity, C. Turbinate bones, D. Olfactory epithelium Correct Option: A
Question 9: A person experiences frequent nosebleeds during the winter season. What could be a contributing factor to this? Options: A. Allergies, B. Infection, C. Dry air, D. Genetics Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of not treating a nosebleed promptly? Options: A. Infection, B. Scarring, C. Difficulty breathing, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey there! Welcome to Life Noggin! If you’ve never had a nosebleed before,
the first one can be terrifying. Especially if you’re young when it happens and have
no idea what’s going on. All you know is that blood is leaking out of your face...for
no reason. But of course, now that you are older you
know that there is a reason your nose started to bleed...you were experiencing a condition
known as epistaxis. When this occurs, it can be one of two types: anterior or posterior.
More than likely, you’ll get an anterior nosebleed which is caused by irritation to
blood vessels in the nasal septum. That’s the part of your nose that separates
your two nostrils. And it’s also the part of your nose that can get deviated, which
can lead to difficulty breathing. And fun fact: it’s estimated that 80% of people
have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum. If I had a nose, I could attest to
that, but sadly my face is pretty featureless. As you can see. But a block can dream! Anyway, in the nasal septum is an area called
the Kiesselbach plexus, where four different arteries come together to form a network of
blood vessels. So, when this area is irritated by either a vigorous blow or a roaming finger,
some of the blood vessels may break. And then you get blood running down your face and possibly
down the back of your throat. But what about dry air? In the northern hemisphere,
winter is coming up and with it comes a lot of nosebleeds. The decreased humidity and
temperature prevent your nose from getting the moisture it needs. This then makes the
mucous membrane more susceptible to bleeding and...Voila! You’ve got blood leaking down
your nostril. The only thing more unappealing than that is saying the words “mucous membrane.” So how do you stop the blood? It’s recommended
that you pinch the soft part of your nose for ten minutes, making sure to keep the nostrils
closed. This pressure helps the blood to clot and stops the bleeding. Oh, and lean forward
during this because otherwise, as I previously mentioned, blood can leak down the back of
your throat. (Which you don't want.) However, if you are lucky enough to be near a doctor when you get a nosebleed,
if they can easily see the broken blood vessel, they may be able to cauterize, or seal, it
using silver nitrate. So do yourself a favor and keep all fingers
and foreign objects away from your nostrils. Your nose and future self will thank you. Have you ever had a nosebleed? Do you get them often?  If you're comfortable with sharing let us know in the comments or tell us what we should we talk about next. And if you want even more Life Noggin, check out this video we did on would happen if all cat suddenly died. Yeah! Oh and make sure you follow us on Facebook and Twitter As always my name is Blocko, this is been life noggin, don't forget to keep on thinking.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An estimated __% of people have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum.
Options: A. 20, B. 40, C. 65, D. 80
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the medical term for a nosebleed? Options: A. Epistaxis, B. Rhinitis, C. Sinusitis, D. Pharyngitis Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which part of the nose separates the two nostrils and can get deviated, leading to difficulty breathing? Options: A. Nasal cavity, B. Nasal septum, C. Turbinate bones, D. Olfactory epithelium Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the estimated percentage of people who have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum? Options: A. 40%, B. 60%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 4: A person experiences a nosebleed due to dry air. What is the likely cause of the bleeding? Options: A. Increased humidity and temperature, B. Decreased humidity and temperature, C. Allergies, D. Infection Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the recommended method to stop a nosebleed? Options: A. Pinch the hard part of the nose for 5 minutes, B. Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes, C. Apply ice to the nose, D. Use nasal decongestants Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is it recommended to lean forward while trying to stop a nosebleed? Options: A. To prevent blood from leaking down the back of the throat, B. To increase blood flow to the nose, C. To reduce swelling, D. To ease breathing Correct Option: A
Question 7: If a doctor can easily see the broken blood vessel, what method may they use to stop the bleeding? Options: A. Cauterization with silver nitrate, B. Nasal packing, C. Antibiotics, D. Surgery Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the name of the area in the nasal septum where four different arteries come together to form a network of blood vessels? Options: A. Kiesselbach plexus, B. Nasal cavity, C. Turbinate bones, D. Olfactory epithelium Correct Option: A
Question 9: A person experiences frequent nosebleeds during the winter season. What could be a contributing factor to this? Options: A. Allergies, B. Infection, C. Dry air, D. Genetics Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of not treating a nosebleed promptly? Options: A. Infection, B. Scarring, C. Difficulty breathing, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What is the estimated percentage of people who have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum? Options: A. 40%, B. 60%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’ve been chosen as a champion 
to represent your wizarding house in a deadly duel against
two rival magic schools. Your opponents are fearsome. From the Newt-niz school, a powerful sorcerer wields a wand
that can turn people into fish, but his spell only works 70% of the time. And from the Leib-ton school, an even more powerful enchantress wields 
a wand that turns people to statues, and it works 90% of the time. Lots are drawn, and you’re chosen 
to cast the first spell in the duel. The Newt-niz magician will go second, and the Leib-ton enchantress third, after which you’ll repeat casting in
that order until only one of you is left. The rules of magic duels are strict, and anyone who casts out of
order immediately forfeits the duel. Also, to prevent draws, the rules stipulate that 
if everyone’s still standing at the end of the first round, you’ll all be turned into cats. Now, you must choose a wand. Your wizarding house presents you 
with three options: the Bannekar, which binds 
one target with vines and casts effectively 60% of the time, the Gaussian, 
which turns one target into a tree and works 80% of the time, and the incredibly rare Noether 9000, which banishes one target 
to a distant mountaintop and casts perfectly 100% of the time. Your opponents are masters of strategy, 
as well as sorcery, and you know they’ll make the choices that
maximize their own chances of success. Which wand should you choose and what strategy should you employ to have the greatest chance 
of winning the duel? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 You reach for the Noether 9000 first. After all, it makes sense to enter 
the duel with the most powerful wand. But before you pick it up, you consider 
what would happen. As the most dangerous wizard, you’d also be the target 
of the other two magicians, and you’d need to take 
care of the most dangerous of them first. But afterward, there’s a 70% chance you'd
be struck down by the remaining wizard. That’s trouble. Maybe it’s better to take the Gaussian. It works 80% of the time, which means you wouldn’t be a target
until the enchantress was incapacitated. But if you succeeded in transforming her, you’d probably be turned 
into a fish immediately after. If you transformed the sorcerer, the enchantress would almost 
certainly turn you to stone. It would really be better if you missed. And that’s when you have an idea: what if you took the Gaussian, 
then missed on purpose? Then, you would wait for the sorcerer 
to attack the enchantress, and you’d have an 80% chance 
of winning against the sorcerer. It’s a good idea, but there’s a problem; the sorcerer could also pass his turn and the enchantress, knowing that
she couldn’t pass without becoming a cat, would cast her spell on one of you. And since you’re the most dangerous 
between you and the sorcerer, you’d be the target. And that’s when you see 
what you really need to do: take the weakest wand, the Bannekar,
and miss on purpose. Now the sorcerer knows that 
he’ll be targeted by the enchantress and he’ll have to try to turn her into 
a fish to avoid being turned into stone. Seventy percent of the time he’d succeed and you’d have a 60% chance 
of winning the duel at the beginning of the next round. If he fails, chances are he’ll be 
turned to stone and you’d still have a 60% chance of
winning the duel against the enchantress. There’s a slim 3% chance 
you’ll all be turned into cats, but when everything’s accounted for, you have better than even odds 
of winning with this strategy. And that’s the best you can do. Here’s what the probability of winning 
for the different strategies looks like. Who would’ve thought 
that the best way to take your shot would be to throw away your shot?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these statements is not the same as saying a wand works 80% of the time?
Options: A. It works 3 out of every 5 times, B. It works 16 out of every 20 times, C. It works 80 out of every 100 times, D. It works 8 out of every 10 times
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the probability of the Newt-niz magician's wand working successfully? Options: A. 60%, B. 70%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the consequence of all duelists still standing at the end of the first round? Options: A. The duel continues as normal., B. All duelists are turned into cats., C. The duel is forfeited by all participants., D. The duel restarts from the beginning. Correct Option: B
Question 3: You are considering choosing the Noether 9000 wand. What is the potential drawback of this choice? Options: A. It has a low probability of success., B. It would make you the primary target of the other two magicians., C. It would not be effective against the enchantress., D. It would not be effective against the sorcerer. Correct Option: B
Question 4: If you choose the Gaussian wand and successfully transform the enchantress, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. You would be turned into a fish by the sorcerer., B. You would be turned into stone by the enchantress., C. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. The sorcerer would attack the enchantress. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the strategic advantage of intentionally missing with the Gaussian wand? Options: A. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., B. You would be able to attack the enchantress first., C. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the enchantress., D. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why is choosing the Bannekar wand and intentionally missing a good strategy? Options: A. It would allow you to attack the enchantress first., B. It would make the sorcerer the primary target of the enchantress., C. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 7: If the sorcerer fails to turn the enchantress into a fish, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. The enchantress would turn the sorcerer into stone., B. The enchantress would turn you into stone., C. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress., D. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the probability of all duelists being turned into cats if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 3%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the primary advantage of choosing the Bannekar wand over the Gaussian wand? Options: A. The Bannekar wand has a higher probability of success., B. The Bannekar wand would make you less of a target for the enchantress., C. The Bannekar wand would allow you to attack the sorcerer first., D. The Bannekar wand would give you a higher chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall probability of winning the duel if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. Less than 50%, B. Exactly 50%, C. Greater than 50%, D. Unknown Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the concept of probability, which is the core idea of the ground truth MCQ.

The generated MCQ that comes closest to the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What is the probability of the Newt-niz magician's wand working successfully? Options: A. 60%, B. 70%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: B**

Although this question does not directly ask about the equivalence of different probability statements, it does involve understanding probability values, which is a related concept.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ, but please note that it's not a perfect match.

Index: 1

that order until only one of you is left. The rules of magic duels are strict, and anyone who casts out of
order immediately forfeits the duel. Also, to prevent draws, the rules stipulate that 
if everyone’s still standing at the end of the first round, you’ll all be turned into cats. Now, you must choose a wand. Your wizarding house presents you 
with three options: the Bannekar, which binds 
one target with vines and casts effectively 60% of the time, the Gaussian, 
which turns one target into a tree and works 80% of the time, and the incredibly rare Noether 9000, which banishes one target 
to a distant mountaintop and casts perfectly 100% of the time. Your opponents are masters of strategy, 
as well as sorcery, and you know they’ll make the choices that
maximize their own chances of success. Which wand should you choose and what strategy should you employ to have the greatest chance 
of winning the duel? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 You reach for the Noether 9000 first. After all, it makes sense to enter 
the duel with the most powerful wand. But before you pick it up, you consider 
what would happen. As the most dangerous wizard, you’d also be the target 
of the other two magicians, and you’d need to take

then missed on purpose? Then, you would wait for the sorcerer 
to attack the enchantress, and you’d have an 80% chance 
of winning against the sorcerer. It’s a good idea, but there’s a problem; the sorcerer could also pass his turn and the enchantress, knowing that
she couldn’t pass without becoming a cat, would cast her spell on one of you. And since you’re the most dangerous

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a duel between the sorcerer and the enchantress, if the sorcerer cast first, who would be more likely to win?
Options: A. The sorcerer, B. The enchantress, C. They are both equally likely to win the duel, D. Not enough information to determine the answer
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What is the probability of the Newt-niz magician's wand working successfully? Options: A. 60%, B. 70%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the consequence of all duelists still standing at the end of the first round? Options: A. The duel continues as normal., B. All duelists are turned into cats., C. The duel is forfeited by all participants., D. The duel restarts from the beginning. Correct Option: B
Question 3: You are considering choosing the Noether 9000 wand. What is the potential drawback of this choice? Options: A. It has a low probability of success., B. It would make you the primary target of the other two magicians., C. It would not be effective against the enchantress., D. It would not be effective against the sorcerer. Correct Option: B
Question 4: If you choose the Gaussian wand and successfully transform the enchantress, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. You would be turned into a fish by the sorcerer., B. You would be turned into stone by the enchantress., C. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. The sorcerer would attack the enchantress. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the strategic advantage of intentionally missing with the Gaussian wand? Options: A. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., B. You would be able to attack the enchantress first., C. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the enchantress., D. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why is choosing the Bannekar wand and intentionally missing a good strategy? Options: A. It would allow you to attack the enchantress first., B. It would make the sorcerer the primary target of the enchantress., C. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 7: If the sorcerer fails to turn the enchantress into a fish, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. The enchantress would turn the sorcerer into stone., B. The enchantress would turn you into stone., C. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress., D. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the probability of all duelists being turned into cats if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 3%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the primary advantage of choosing the Bannekar wand over the Gaussian wand? Options: A. The Bannekar wand has a higher probability of success., B. The Bannekar wand would make you less of a target for the enchantress., C. The Bannekar wand would allow you to attack the sorcerer first., D. The Bannekar wand would give you a higher chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall probability of winning the duel if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. Less than 50%, B. Exactly 50%, C. Greater than 50%, D. Unknown Correct Option: C

The ground truth MCQ asks about the enchantress's chance of winning the duel if she casts first in a duel between her and the sorcerer. The most similar generated MCQ is Question 7, which asks about the outcome if the sorcerer fails to turn the enchantress into a fish. Although it's not a direct match, it's related to the enchantress's chances in a duel against the sorcerer.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is more similar in terms of intent and content, I would suggest Question 4. It asks about the outcome if you choose the Gaussian wand and successfully transform the enchantress, which is related to the enchantress's chances in a duel.

But since neither of these questions directly matches the ground truth MCQ, I would say that there is no generated MCQ that closely matches the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say: Question 4 (with the caveat that it's not a direct match).

Index: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’ve been chosen as a champion 
to represent your wizarding house in a deadly duel against
two rival magic schools. Your opponents are fearsome. From the Newt-niz school, a powerful sorcerer wields a wand
that can turn people into fish, but his spell only works 70% of the time. And from the Leib-ton school, an even more powerful enchantress wields 
a wand that turns people to statues, and it works 90% of the time. Lots are drawn, and you’re chosen 
to cast the first spell in the duel. The Newt-niz magician will go second, and the Leib-ton enchantress third, after which you’ll repeat casting in
that order until only one of you is left. The rules of magic duels are strict, and anyone who casts out of
order immediately forfeits the duel. Also, to prevent draws, the rules stipulate that 
if everyone’s still standing at the end of the first round, you’ll all be turned into cats. Now, you must choose a wand. Your wizarding house presents you 
with three options: the Bannekar, which binds 
one target with vines and casts effectively 60% of the time, the Gaussian, 
which turns one target into a tree and works 80% of the time, and the incredibly rare Noether 9000, which banishes one target 
to a distant mountaintop and casts perfectly 100% of the time. Your opponents are masters of strategy, 
as well as sorcery, and you know they’ll make the choices that
maximize their own chances of success. Which wand should you choose and what strategy should you employ to have the greatest chance 
of winning the duel? Pause the video now if you want
to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 You reach for the Noether 9000 first. After all, it makes sense to enter 
the duel with the most powerful wand. But before you pick it up, you consider 
what would happen. As the most dangerous wizard, you’d also be the target 
of the other two magicians, and you’d need to take 
care of the most dangerous of them first. But afterward, there’s a 70% chance you'd
be struck down by the remaining wizard. That’s trouble. Maybe it’s better to take the Gaussian. It works 80% of the time, which means you wouldn’t be a target
until the enchantress was incapacitated. But if you succeeded in transforming her, you’d probably be turned 
into a fish immediately after. If you transformed the sorcerer, the enchantress would almost 
certainly turn you to stone. It would really be better if you missed. And that’s when you have an idea: what if you took the Gaussian, 
then missed on purpose? Then, you would wait for the sorcerer 
to attack the enchantress, and you’d have an 80% chance 
of winning against the sorcerer. It’s a good idea, but there’s a problem; the sorcerer could also pass his turn and the enchantress, knowing that
she couldn’t pass without becoming a cat, would cast her spell on one of you. And since you’re the most dangerous 
between you and the sorcerer, you’d be the target. And that’s when you see 
what you really need to do: take the weakest wand, the Bannekar,
and miss on purpose. Now the sorcerer knows that 
he’ll be targeted by the enchantress and he’ll have to try to turn her into 
a fish to avoid being turned into stone. Seventy percent of the time he’d succeed and you’d have a 60% chance 
of winning the duel at the beginning of the next round. If he fails, chances are he’ll be 
turned to stone and you’d still have a 60% chance of
winning the duel against the enchantress. There’s a slim 3% chance 
you’ll all be turned into cats, but when everything’s accounted for, you have better than even odds 
of winning with this strategy. And that’s the best you can do. Here’s what the probability of winning 
for the different strategies looks like. Who would’ve thought 
that the best way to take your shot would be to throw away your shot?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Bannekar casts effectively _______ of the time.
Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 60%, D. 100%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the probability of the Newt-niz magician's wand working successfully? Options: A. 60%, B. 70%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the consequence of all duelists still standing at the end of the first round? Options: A. The duel continues as normal., B. All duelists are turned into cats., C. The duel is forfeited by all participants., D. The duel restarts from the beginning. Correct Option: B
Question 3: You are considering choosing the Noether 9000 wand. What is the potential drawback of this choice? Options: A. It has a low probability of success., B. It would make you the primary target of the other two magicians., C. It would not be effective against the enchantress., D. It would not be effective against the sorcerer. Correct Option: B
Question 4: If you choose the Gaussian wand and successfully transform the enchantress, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. You would be turned into a fish by the sorcerer., B. You would be turned into stone by the enchantress., C. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. The sorcerer would attack the enchantress. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the strategic advantage of intentionally missing with the Gaussian wand? Options: A. You would have an 80% chance of winning against the sorcerer., B. You would be able to attack the enchantress first., C. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the enchantress., D. You would be able to avoid being targeted by the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why is choosing the Bannekar wand and intentionally missing a good strategy? Options: A. It would allow you to attack the enchantress first., B. It would make the sorcerer the primary target of the enchantress., C. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer., D. It would give you a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 7: If the sorcerer fails to turn the enchantress into a fish, what is likely to happen next? Options: A. The enchantress would turn the sorcerer into stone., B. The enchantress would turn you into stone., C. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the enchantress., D. You would have a 60% chance of winning against the sorcerer. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the probability of all duelists being turned into cats if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 3%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the primary advantage of choosing the Bannekar wand over the Gaussian wand? Options: A. The Bannekar wand has a higher probability of success., B. The Bannekar wand would make you less of a target for the enchantress., C. The Bannekar wand would allow you to attack the sorcerer first., D. The Bannekar wand would give you a higher chance of winning against the enchantress. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall probability of winning the duel if you choose the Bannekar wand and intentionally miss? Options: A. Less than 50%, B. Exactly 50%, C. Greater than 50%, D. Unknown Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although Question 1 does not directly ask about the Bannekar wand, it is the only generated MCQ that asks about the probability of a wand working successfully, which is the same type of information being asked in the ground truth MCQ. However, there isn't a direct match for the ground truth MCQ among the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar one based on the given options, I would say Question 1 is the closest match, but with a different wand being asked about.

that order until only one of you is left. The rules of magic duels are strict, and anyone who casts out of
order immediately forfeits the duel. Also, to prevent draws, the rules stipulate that 
if everyone’s still standing at the end of the first round, you’ll all be turned into cats. Now, you must choose a wand. Your wizarding house presents you 
with three options: the Bannekar, which binds

which turns one target into a tree and works 80% of the time, and the incredibly rare Noether 9000, which banishes one target

of winning the duel? Pause the video now if you want

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You probably know the drill: You’re handed
an exam, and you’re told you need to fill out the bubbles completely, and then reminded
that -- for reasons that no one ever explains -- you can only use a number 2 pencil! Now, unless you’re an artist, you’ve probably
never even seen a pencil that’s not number 2, also known as an HB pencil outside the
U.S. The thing is, if you used any other kind of
pencil when you took an automatically-scored test, you’d probably be fine. However there are reasons that test instructions
still tell you to stick to number 2. And they have a lot to do with how machines
score your tests -- or at least, how they used to. In 1931, a high school physics teacher named
Reynold Johnson was grading exams when he wondered if there might be a way to score
them without actually having to go through every single answer by hand. He knew that graphite, the writing material
in pencils, was electrically conductive. It’s made of flat sheets of carbon, and
its outer electrons are relatively free to move around within the material. So Johnson devised a machine with many small
electrical circuits that would pass over an answer sheet. If there was a pencil mark on the sheet, it
would conduct electricity through one of the circuits, and the machine could record it
as an answer. Eventually, he sold the idea to IBM, which
produced the first mark-sensing machines. But the number 2 thing didn’t become an
issue until the next generation of machines were introduced in the 1960s and 70s. Those machines had light-sensing devices called
phototubes, and if they did not detect light in a certain spot, they recorded it as an
answer. That made graphite especially useful, because
it’s better at blocking light than many inks. Graphite reflects most light -- that’s why
pencil marks are so shiny -- and absorbs the rest, which is why it’s black. But for a long time, these optical mark-sensing
machines were very picky. And that’s where the different grades of
pencil came in. The graphite in pencils is held together by
clay, so manufacturers can control how soft or hard it is, and also how dark it is. The softer the graphite, the darker the pencil’s
mark. Pencils are labeled accordingly. In the United States, those labels are numbers. International manufacturers use a different
system, with HB corresponding to number 2. Number 2 pencils make marks that are just
dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased without leaving
a readable mark. These days, scoring machines use much more
advanced sensors that can detect almost any sort of marks you make, as long as they’re
in the bubbles. So you could probably take your next exam
with any kind of pencil you wanted. But your SATs probably aren’t the time to
test that hypothesis. Maybe bring a couple of number 2’s just
to be safe. Thanks for asking, and thanks especially to
all of our supporters on Patreon, where, if you support us at four dollars per month or
more, you can submit your questions to be answered right here on SciShow Quick Questions. And if you want to keep getting smarter with
us, don’t forget to go to youtube.com/scishow, and subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Outside the United States, what is a #2 pencil known as?
Options: A. HB, B. H, C. 2H, D. B
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pencil is commonly recommended for use on automatically-scored tests in the United States? Options: A. Number 1 pencil, B. Number 2 pencil, C. Number 3 pencil, D. Number 4 pencil Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason why graphite is useful for scoring tests with machines? Options: A. It is electrically conductive and can block light, B. It is only found in number 2 pencils, C. It is a soft material that can be easily erased, D. It is a hard material that can be easily detected Correct Option: A
Question 3: If you were to design a new test-scoring machine, what type of sensor would you use to detect pencil marks, considering the advancements in technology? Options: A. Phototubes, B. Electrical circuits, C. Advanced optical sensors, D. Thermal sensors Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the clay in pencil lead, and how does it affect the pencil's performance? Options: A. The clay makes the pencil lead harder and more prone to breakage, B. The clay makes the pencil lead softer and more prone to smudging, C. The clay helps control the softness and darkness of the pencil lead, D. The clay has no effect on the pencil's performance Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do optical mark-sensing machines detect pencil marks, and what makes graphite useful for this purpose? Options: A. The machines detect light reflected by the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it absorbs most light, B. The machines detect light absorbed by the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it reflects most light, C. The machines detect the electrical conductivity of the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it is electrically conductive, D. The machines detect the darkness of the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it is a dark material Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the difference between the labeling systems used by pencil manufacturers in the United States and internationally? Options: A. The United States uses letters (HB, 2B, 4B, etc.), while international manufacturers use numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), B. The United States uses numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), while international manufacturers use letters (HB, 2B, 4B, etc.), C. The United States uses a combination of letters and numbers, while international manufacturers use only numbers, D. The United States uses only numbers, while international manufacturers use a combination of letters and numbers Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why are number 2 pencils recommended for use on tests, considering the characteristics of the graphite and the scoring machines? Options: A. Number 2 pencils make marks that are too dark and may not be erased properly, B. Number 2 pencils make marks that are too light and may not be detected by the machines, C. Number 2 pencils make marks that are just dark enough to be sensed by the machines, but also light enough to be erased without leaving a readable mark, D. Number 2 pencils are the only type of pencil that can be used on tests Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary advantage of using advanced sensors in modern test-scoring machines? Options: A. They can only detect marks made with number 2 pencils, B. They can detect almost any sort of marks, as long as they are in the bubbles, C. They are more prone to errors and require manual correction, D. They are more expensive and less efficient than older machines Correct Option: B
Question 9: Who devised the first machine that could score tests automatically, and what was the basis for his invention? Options: A. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the electrical conductivity of graphite to devise a machine with electrical circuits, B. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the reflectivity of graphite to devise a machine with phototubes, C. IBM, a technology company, which developed a machine that could score tests automatically using advanced sensors, D. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the darkness of graphite to devise a machine with optical sensors Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main reason why it is still recommended to use number 2 pencils on tests, despite the advancements in scoring machine technology? Options: A. The machines are still picky and may not detect marks made with other types of pencils, B. The number 2 pencils are the only type of pencil that can be used on tests, C. It is a tradition that has been passed down through the years, D. It is better to be safe than sorry, and using number 2 pencils ensures that the marks will be detected by the machines Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the labeling system used by pencil manufacturers in the United States and internationally. The options provided in Question 6 also match the information provided in the ground truth MCQ, with option B stating that the United States uses numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), while international manufacturers use letters (HB, 2B, 4B, etc.). This matches the information provided in the ground truth MCQ, which states that a #2 pencil is known as an HB pencil outside the United States.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 6.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You probably know the drill: You’re handed
an exam, and you’re told you need to fill out the bubbles completely, and then reminded
that -- for reasons that no one ever explains -- you can only use a number 2 pencil! Now, unless you’re an artist, you’ve probably
never even seen a pencil that’s not number 2, also known as an HB pencil outside the
U.S. The thing is, if you used any other kind of
pencil when you took an automatically-scored test, you’d probably be fine. However there are reasons that test instructions
still tell you to stick to number 2. And they have a lot to do with how machines
score your tests -- or at least, how they used to. In 1931, a high school physics teacher named
Reynold Johnson was grading exams when he wondered if there might be a way to score
them without actually having to go through every single answer by hand. He knew that graphite, the writing material
in pencils, was electrically conductive. It’s made of flat sheets of carbon, and
its outer electrons are relatively free to move around within the material. So Johnson devised a machine with many small
electrical circuits that would pass over an answer sheet. If there was a pencil mark on the sheet, it
would conduct electricity through one of the circuits, and the machine could record it
as an answer. Eventually, he sold the idea to IBM, which
produced the first mark-sensing machines. But the number 2 thing didn’t become an
issue until the next generation of machines were introduced in the 1960s and 70s. Those machines had light-sensing devices called
phototubes, and if they did not detect light in a certain spot, they recorded it as an
answer. That made graphite especially useful, because
it’s better at blocking light than many inks. Graphite reflects most light -- that’s why
pencil marks are so shiny -- and absorbs the rest, which is why it’s black. But for a long time, these optical mark-sensing
machines were very picky. And that’s where the different grades of
pencil came in. The graphite in pencils is held together by
clay, so manufacturers can control how soft or hard it is, and also how dark it is. The softer the graphite, the darker the pencil’s
mark. Pencils are labeled accordingly. In the United States, those labels are numbers. International manufacturers use a different
system, with HB corresponding to number 2. Number 2 pencils make marks that are just
dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased without leaving
a readable mark. These days, scoring machines use much more
advanced sensors that can detect almost any sort of marks you make, as long as they’re
in the bubbles. So you could probably take your next exam
with any kind of pencil you wanted. But your SATs probably aren’t the time to
test that hypothesis. Maybe bring a couple of number 2’s just
to be safe. Thanks for asking, and thanks especially to
all of our supporters on Patreon, where, if you support us at four dollars per month or
more, you can submit your questions to be answered right here on SciShow Quick Questions. And if you want to keep getting smarter with
us, don’t forget to go to youtube.com/scishow, and subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Graphite reflects ____ light, which is why it’s black.
Options: A. little, B. most
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pencil is commonly recommended for use on automatically-scored tests in the United States? Options: A. Number 1 pencil, B. Number 2 pencil, C. Number 3 pencil, D. Number 4 pencil Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason why graphite is useful for scoring tests with machines? Options: A. It is electrically conductive and can block light, B. It is only found in number 2 pencils, C. It is a soft material that can be easily erased, D. It is a hard material that can be easily detected Correct Option: A
Question 3: If you were to design a new test-scoring machine, what type of sensor would you use to detect pencil marks, considering the advancements in technology? Options: A. Phototubes, B. Electrical circuits, C. Advanced optical sensors, D. Thermal sensors Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the clay in pencil lead, and how does it affect the pencil's performance? Options: A. The clay makes the pencil lead harder and more prone to breakage, B. The clay makes the pencil lead softer and more prone to smudging, C. The clay helps control the softness and darkness of the pencil lead, D. The clay has no effect on the pencil's performance Correct Option: C
Question 5: How do optical mark-sensing machines detect pencil marks, and what makes graphite useful for this purpose? Options: A. The machines detect light reflected by the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it absorbs most light, B. The machines detect light absorbed by the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it reflects most light, C. The machines detect the electrical conductivity of the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it is electrically conductive, D. The machines detect the darkness of the pencil mark, and graphite is useful because it is a dark material Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the difference between the labeling systems used by pencil manufacturers in the United States and internationally? Options: A. The United States uses letters (HB, 2B, 4B, etc.), while international manufacturers use numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), B. The United States uses numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.), while international manufacturers use letters (HB, 2B, 4B, etc.), C. The United States uses a combination of letters and numbers, while international manufacturers use only numbers, D. The United States uses only numbers, while international manufacturers use a combination of letters and numbers Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why are number 2 pencils recommended for use on tests, considering the characteristics of the graphite and the scoring machines? Options: A. Number 2 pencils make marks that are too dark and may not be erased properly, B. Number 2 pencils make marks that are too light and may not be detected by the machines, C. Number 2 pencils make marks that are just dark enough to be sensed by the machines, but also light enough to be erased without leaving a readable mark, D. Number 2 pencils are the only type of pencil that can be used on tests Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the primary advantage of using advanced sensors in modern test-scoring machines? Options: A. They can only detect marks made with number 2 pencils, B. They can detect almost any sort of marks, as long as they are in the bubbles, C. They are more prone to errors and require manual correction, D. They are more expensive and less efficient than older machines Correct Option: B
Question 9: Who devised the first machine that could score tests automatically, and what was the basis for his invention? Options: A. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the electrical conductivity of graphite to devise a machine with electrical circuits, B. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the reflectivity of graphite to devise a machine with phototubes, C. IBM, a technology company, which developed a machine that could score tests automatically using advanced sensors, D. Reynold Johnson, a high school physics teacher, who used the darkness of graphite to devise a machine with optical sensors Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main reason why it is still recommended to use number 2 pencils on tests, despite the advancements in scoring machine technology? Options: A. The machines are still picky and may not detect marks made with other types of pencils, B. The number 2 pencils are the only type of pencil that can be used on tests, C. It is a tradition that has been passed down through the years, D. It is better to be safe than sorry, and using number 2 pencils ensures that the marks will be detected by the machines Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One of the greatest and cruelest joys in the
world is tickling. I mean, who doesn't enjoy making somebody
laugh? Especially when they can't help but laugh. But when you think about it, tickling -- that's
just a weird thing. What is that? Why does it exist? The word "tickling" is actually an umbrella
term for two different phenomena. The first we're going to talk about is knismesis. That's the kind of itchy feeling that you
get when somebody puts a feather on your sensitive skin and it's like gnaaaah. That sensation creates a desire to, like,
rub or scratch, but it doesn't cause you to laugh. That kind of tickling is called gargalesis,
which is caused by a harder touch or stroke that unleashes a confusing cocktail of pain
and pleasure into the brain. Now, knismesis makes sense. If an insect or spider crawls on your leg,
you feel a tickling sensation, and you, you get it off. Knismesis is widespread in mammals: a horse
whips its tail when a fly lands on its back, and a cat's ears twitch when you brush 'em. Gargalesis, on the other hand -- and I love
that word -- is only experienced by primates, which include humans. When you tickle a chimp, it lets out a noiseless
pant that is the evolutionary precursor to a human laugh. And all us primates are ticklish in the same
spots: The ribs, under the arms, under the chin, near the femoral artery in the leg...
these are all vulnerable areas of the body, leading some psychologists to theorize that
gargalesis is an evolutionary mechanism that young apes and humans use to teach each other
how to protect themselves if attacked, the equivalent of, like, puppies play-fighting. We instinctively curl away from a tickle. We kick and twist, but we also laugh and smile,
which is an encouraging facial expression which tells the tickler, "More! Please!" If tickling induced a negative facial expression,
the thinking goes, then people wouldn't do it to each other, and we wouldn't learn how
to defend ourselves. So the next time you attack your brother with
a storm of tickle-fingers, you can say, "Dude. I'm just teaching you life skills!" Thanks for asking this fascinating question. Who knew it would be so interesting? And thanks especially to our Subbable subscribers,
who get these answers a little early. If you'd like to get a sneak peek or other
perks like a SciShow tie or a SciShow pocket protector, go to subbable.com/scishow. And if you've got a Quick Question, you can
ask us on Facebook or Twitter or Tumblr or down in the comments below, and don't forget
to go to youtube.com/scishow, and subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which sensation causes you to laugh?
Options: A. Gargalesis, B. Knismesis
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the term for the itchy feeling caused by a light touch on sensitive skin? Options: A. Gargalesis, B. Knismesis, C. Tickling, D. Laughter Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which type of tickling is associated with laughter and is unique to primates? Options: A. Knismesis, B. Gargalesis, C. Feather-induced tickling, D. Hard touch tickling Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the possible evolutionary purpose of gargalesis, according to some psychologists? Options: A. To induce laughter and relaxation, B. To teach young apes and humans how to protect themselves from attacks, C. To stimulate the brain's pain centers, D. To promote social bonding Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why do people often curl away from a tickle, yet also laugh and smile? Options: A. Because tickling is a purely pleasurable sensation, B. Because tickling is a way to release tension, C. Because the brain is sending mixed signals of pain and pleasure, D. Because the tickler is encouraged by the laughter to continue Correct Option: C
Question 5: Which areas of the body are commonly ticklish in primates? Options: A. The soles of the feet, the palms of the hands, and the back of the neck, B. The ribs, under the arms, under the chin, and near the femoral artery, C. The forehead, the nose, and the ears, D. The knees, the elbows, and the ankles Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the equivalent behavior in puppies that is similar to gargalesis in primates? Options: A. Play-fighting, B. Chasing, C. Fetching, D. Cuddling Correct Option: A
Question 7: If tickling induced a negative facial expression, what might happen according to the theory? Options: A. People would tickle each other more frequently, B. People would learn to defend themselves more effectively, C. People wouldn't do it to each other, and we wouldn't learn how to defend ourselves, D. Tickling would become a more aggressive behavior Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the name of the phenomenon where a harder touch or stroke unleashes a confusing cocktail of pain and pleasure into the brain? Options: A. Knismesis, B. Gargalesis, C. Tickling, D. Laughter Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do some mammals, like horses and cats, typically respond to knismesis? Options: A. They laugh and smile, B. They become aggressive, C. They rub or scratch the affected area, D. They remain still and calm Correct Option: C
Question 10: What might be a justification for tickling someone, according to the theory discussed in the transcript? Options: A. "I'm just trying to annoy you!", B. "I'm just teaching you life skills!", C. "I'm just trying to make you laugh!", D. "I'm just trying to assert my dominance!" Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the ground truth MCQ contains an error (it states that Knismesis is the sensation that causes laughter, when in fact it is Gargalesis), Question 2 is the closest match in terms of question intent, options, and content. Question 2 correctly identifies Gargalesis as the type of tickling associated with laughter and unique to primates.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

as we grow older we often lose the extreme ends of our hearing Spectrum so how many of the following sounds can you hear how old are your ears okay if you can hear 8,000 Hertz you're both alive and not hearing impaired but let's keep raising the frequency how high could you hear if you could hear all of those frequencies you're probably under 20 years old but that won't last forever unlike other organs such as the liver or skin the inner ear does not have the capacity to regenerate in your ear there are thousands of tiny nerve cells called hair cells these are responsible for picking up different frequencies and sending the signal to the brain where it's processed but as you age the continual exposure to noise and loud sounds can break Bend and Destroy these cells so why do the high frequencies go first it turns out that the hairs tuned to high pitches are the first to encounter sound waves as a result they experience more stress and tend to degenerate earlier which is why the older you are the harder it is to hear high pitches got a burning question you want answered ask it in the comments or on Facebook and Twitter and subscribe for more weekly science videos

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: As you get older, you cannot hear ___ pitches.
Options: A. low, B. high
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of the tiny nerve cells called hair cells in the ear? Options: A. To produce sound waves, B. To pick up different frequencies and send signals to the brain, C. To regulate the ear's temperature, D. To maintain the ear's balance Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens to the high-frequency hair cells as a person ages? Options: A. They become more sensitive, B. They experience less stress, C. They degenerate earlier, D. They remain unchanged Correct Option: C
Question 3: If a person can hear a frequency of 8,000 Hertz, what can be concluded about their hearing? Options: A. They are hearing impaired, B. They are not alive, C. They are both alive and not hearing impaired, D. They have a hearing aid Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why do the high frequencies tend to degenerate earlier than lower frequencies? Options: A. Because they are less exposed to noise, B. Because they are more sensitive to sound waves, C. Because they experience more stress from encountering sound waves first, D. Because they are less important for hearing Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary reason for the loss of hearing in high frequencies as people age? Options: A. The inner ear's inability to regenerate, B. The liver's inability to filter toxins, C. The skin's inability to protect the ear, D. The brain's inability to process sound Correct Option: A
Question 6: A 25-year-old person is having trouble hearing high pitches. What might be a possible explanation for this? Options: A. They are experiencing a natural part of aging, B. They have a rare genetic disorder, C. They have been exposed to excessive loud noises, D. They have a hearing aid that is malfunctioning Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a unique characteristic of the inner ear compared to other organs like the liver or skin? Options: A. Its ability to regenerate, B. Its sensitivity to sound waves, C. Its inability to regenerate, D. Its importance for balance Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the continual exposure to noise and loud sounds affect the hair cells in the ear? Options: A. It strengthens them, B. It has no effect on them, C. It breaks, bends, and destroys them, D. It regenerates them Correct Option: C
Question 9: What would be a likely consequence if a person is exposed to loud noises for an extended period? Options: A. Their hearing will improve, B. Their hearing will remain unchanged, C. They will experience hearing loss, especially in high frequencies, D. They will develop a rare genetic disorder Correct Option: C
Question 10: If a person can hear all frequencies, including the highest ones, what can be inferred about their age? Options: A. They are likely over 50 years old, B. They are likely under 20 years old, C. They are likely between 20-50 years old, D. Their age cannot be determined Correct Option: B
